nodes.text: Conservation of money together with statistical mechanics principles can explain the observed money and income distributions, the spontaneous emergence of inequality, and dynamics of monetary crises
Money is conserved in peer-to-peer transactions among agents (local conservation law of money balances)
The Boltzmann kinetic equation and related statistical mechanics arguments can be applied to an ensemble of economic agents exchanging a conserved quantity (money)
From the kinetic/detailed-balance argument, the stationary probability distribution of money under additive, time-reversible transactions is exponential P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm) with Tm = M/N

Microscopic time-reversal symmetry of transaction rules is a sufficient condition for the exponential stationary distribution, while multiplicative or non-time-reversible rules produce Gamma-like or power-law deviations
Empirical income data (IRS, Census) show a two-class structure: an exponential distribution for the majority (lower class) and a Pareto power-law tail for the upper class
Maximal-entropy principle explains the exponential money distribution as the most probable macrostate under a conserved total money and appropriate boundary conditions

For small transaction increments the Boltzmann equation reduces to a Fokker-Planck (Kolmogorov forward) equation with drift A and diffusion B; additive processes yield exponential stationary solutions (Tm = B/A)

Debt creation effectively removes the lower-boundary condition on agent net worth and therefore destabilizes statistical equilibrium, allowing unbounded negative balances and unbounded growth of entropy
Agent-based simulations that start from equal positive initial money and impose lower-boundary m>0 show spontaneous broadening and relaxation to the stationary exponential distribution
Commercial banks aggregate lending and effectively create debt/liabilities for clients (analogous to particle-antiparticle pair creation); this multiplies debt and can amplify systemic instability

Central bank actions and monetization (exogenous money creation by the state when it purchases assets or absorbs bank losses) transform endogenous bank-created debt into base money and increase money available to financial actors

Empirical evidence (IRS income data and Fig. 1) shows spikes in inequality linked to speculative bubbles and to Quantitative Easing, consistent with the claim that central bank bailouts increase inequality

Conclusion: State (exogenous) money injected during crises is the ultimate source of aggregate capitalist monetary profit and of financing interest and returns that cannot be created solely by internal transactions

Limitation: The analysis focuses on abstract monetary (informational) layer separated from physical production and does not fully account for emerging digital-economy topologies where copying and many-to-many transactions change pricing and monetary roles
Assumption: Imposing a lower boundary condition (e.g., nonnegative money balances m>0 or regulated debt limits) is necessary for achieving a stationary money distribution and preventing runaway debt
